title: 110_s878
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Oil Industry Merger Antitrust Enforcement Act" and includes a statement of findings and declarations of purposes. Congress finds that American consumers are facing high energy prices due to concentration among oil companies, caused by mergers and acquisitions. Antitrust enforcement agencies have failed to prevent this consolidation, harming consumers and competition. The consolidation of oil companies has harmed competition and consumers by giving market power to the remaining companies. The inelastic demand for petroleum products allows companies to raise prices easily. The Act aims to enforce antitrust laws in the oil industry and restore competition in the production, refining, distribution, and marketing of gasoline. The Act aims to prevent market power accumulation by oil companies in the production, refining, distribution, and marketing of petroleum products. The Act aims to prevent market power accumulation by oil companies in the production, refining, distribution, and marketing of petroleum products. SEC. 3. BURDEN OF PROOF. "In any civil action under Section 7 of the Clayton Act, if the plaintiff alleges that a merger may lessen competition in the petroleum industry and involves competing businesses, they must establish this." "In civil actions under Section 7 of the Clayton Act, the burden of proof is on the defendant to show that a merger will not harm competition in the petroleum industry." SEC. 4. ENSURING FULL AND FREE COMPETITION. The Federal Trade Commission and the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice will review and revise enforcement guidelines to address mergers and acquisitions in the oil industry, ensuring competition is not substantially lessened or a monopoly created. The guidelines for mergers and acquisitions in the oil industry will be revised to consider specific conditions such as high demand inelasticity, market power ease, capacity limits, entry barriers, and regulatory requirements. The review must be completed within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Federal Trade Commission and the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice must report to Congress within 6 months on the review and revision of enforcement guidelines for mergers and acquisitions in the oil industry. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS.

In this Act, "oil industry" refers to companies and individuals involved in oil or petroleum-based products' production, refining, distribution, or marketing. "Petroleum-based product" includes gasoline, diesel fuel, jet fuel, home heating oil, natural gas, and other products from oil or petroleum refining.
